docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: John Horgan (Op-Ed, March 21) claims that in the past century ''there have been virtually no genuine advances in treatments for depression and other common mental disorders.'' But research has demonstrated the efficacy of new antidepressant drugs and psychotherapies. All outperform placebos, and some likely outperform others. Mr. Horgan calls psychoanalysis and Prozac equivalent treatments, yet Prozac has strong empirical support while psychoanalysis has never been tested for depression.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: John Horgan's assessment of treatments for depression (Op-Ed, March 21) is unduly pessimistic. Depression has a natural history of improvement over time and, at times, recurrence. However, various treatments help sufferers to recover more rapidly than they otherwise might and can prevent the return of depression.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs has for the first time suspended all research in one of its health care centers, saying the center has failed to meet ethical guidelines in human experiments. After six years of investigations and temporary suspensions, the hospitals and clinics of the Veterans Affairs of Greater Los Angeles Health Care System -- including the West Los Angeles Veterans Affairs Medical Center, one of the nation's largest research hospitals -- were ordered on Monday to halt all of their animal and human experiments. The order will go into effect on Friday.

headline.main: V.A. Hospital Is Told to Halt All Research

docs.abstract: Department of Veterans Affairs for first time suspends all research in one of its health care centers, ordering clinics of Greater Los Angeles Health Care System to halt animal and human experiments for allegedly failing to meet ethical guidelines in human experiments; Veterans Affairs Under Sec Dr Kenneth W Kizer orders shutdown; notes hospitals were already on probation and says management has repeatedly failed to correct problems; cuts off all private funds; Department of Health and Human Services officialls halts all Federal financing; problems mainly involve experiments carried out mentally ill veterans; patients' advocates charge some were deliberately taken off medications and allowed to suffer relapses so researchers could study course of symptoms, and that others were intentionally given drugs that made symptoms worse so doctors could observe them as they occurred (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A generation ago, Dr. Ancel Keys and colleagues at the University of Minnesota published findings that, if heeded then, would have extended millions of American lives during the last 30 years and millions more in the years to come. The researchers examined the relationship between diet and heart disease rates in seven countries and found that people who lived along the Mediterranean Sea suffered only a tiny fraction of the heart attacks and coronary deaths experienced by Americans and people in other Western industrialized countries. Among people along the Mediterranean, dietary fat consumed was mostly of vegetable origin; among the others, diets were rich in highly saturated animal fats from meat and dairy products.

headline.main: Savory Diet That's Good For Heart? Let's Eat

docs.lead_paragraph: A Government-commissioned panel of experts reported last week that there had been ''an explosion of new scientific knowledge'' on the medical uses of marijuana. The chemicals in marijuana, they concluded, can fight the nausea induced by chemotherapy, boost the appetites of AIDS patients and ameliorate some symptoms of multiple sclerosis. The report was no news to me. I had reached the same conclusions as a cancer patient, seven years ago. In 1992 I was found to have testicular cancer. My chemotherapy put me in the hospital for five days at a time, once a month, for four months. But midway through my treatment I could tell that Zofran, then a hot new drug prescribed to combat nausea, was losing its effect. For the remainder of my chemotherapy I turned to marijuana to keep my head out of the toilet.

headline.main: A Drug War Against the Sick
